journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment

title-group.article-title: Applying fuzzy quality function deployment to evaluate solutions of the service quality for international port logistics centres in Taiwan

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Shipping and Transportation Management, National Taiwan Ocean University, Keelung, Taiwan, ROC
2Department of Aviation and Maritime Transportation Management, Chang Jung Christian University, Tainan City, Taiwan, ROC

author-notes.corresp: Ji-Feng Ding, Department of Aviation and Maritime Transportation Management, Chang Jung Christian University, Tainan 711, Taiwan, ROC. Email: jfding@mail.cjcu.edu.tw

abstract.p: The main purpose of this paper is to apply the fuzzy quality function deployment approach to evaluate solutions of the service quality for international port logistics centres in Taiwan. First, the paper examines house-of-quality matrices to facilitate handling of the ‘what’ aspects (i.e. requirements of the service quality) and the ‘how’ aspects (i.e. solutions of the service quality) of the quality function deployment problem. In conjunction with fuzzy sets theory, systematic procedures using the fuzzy quality function deployment approach were proposed in this paper. Subsequently, a case study concerning an international port logistics centre Z in Taiwan is utilized to demonstrate the systematic appraisal process for evaluating solutions of the service quality. Then, 34 attributes with 11 feasible solutions of the service quality of customer requirements are measured by employing the house-of-quality matrices. Finally, the empirical results show that the top five feasible solutions of the service quality of customer requirements for the port logistics centre Z are identified. They consist of ‘service personnel’s professionalism’, ‘a complete information system’, ‘the ability to track cargoes’, ‘service personnel’s response ability’ and ‘strengthening of warehousing security management’ respectively. Furthermore, some discussion is given on these five feasible solutions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As all industries in the world have entered a new labour division system in the supply chain, many enterprises are now engaging in purchasing and production activities in different countries and distribute their products to different nations around the world. These circumstances have led to the booming development of the logistics industry. In the international logistics and transport system, the port system plays an important role in connecting the competing environments of sea and land transport.1 With the increasing development of the logistics industry, the role of port logistics centres (PLCs) is becoming more and more important.2,3 To provide international enterprises with a higher quality of logistics services, international ports around the world (e.g. Singapore and Rotterdam) have been working hard to develop port logistics services to enhance their competitiveness. The operators of PLCs are hoping to build a highly efficient distribution environment to make the whole transport process more cost effective and to provide superior quality in the logistics activities.

However, with the growing demand for goods and services, the focus of goods and services has shifted from cost orientation to customer orientation. This leads to the prevalence of quality management and more emphasis on the service quality.2,4 Under these circumstances, the quality of service has become one of the key factors influencing selection of PLCs for customers and, thus, will further affect the logistics centre’s performance. This has also compelled logistics centres to focus on their service qualities.

Port logistics services are a type of service industry, but there are discrepancies in the perceived importance and satisfaction when the service quality is provided by the port logistics service providers (PLSPs).3,4 In order to enhance the service quality performance, executable and feasible solutions must be proposed in order to resolve the issue of these discrepancy problems. Therefore, how the service quality can be improved has now become an urgent task for PLSPs. As a result, how customer demands for services can be converted into technical solutions needed to upgrade the service quality and how workable plans can be produced and priorities implemented are both very important to PLSPs. In light of these circumstances, the quality function deployment (QFD) method4–7 offers a suitable solution approach. Furthermore, there are situations in which information is incomplete or imprecise or there are views that are subjective or endowed with linguistic characteristics,8 creating a ‘fuzzy’9 decision-making environment. The fuzziness-based quality function deployment (fuzzy QFD) approach can be used to evaluate the relationships between customer requirements and technical solutions of the service quality for the PLSPs. By using the fuzzy QFD approach, the service quality of customer requirements can be transformed into technical solutions able to improve the service quality performance.

In summary, the main purpose of this paper is to apply the fuzzy QFD approach to evaluate technical solutions of the service quality for international PLCs in Taiwan. The first section provides some background information concerning this issue. The second section presents the research methodology, and the third section describes the fuzzy QFD procedures. The fourth section consists of an empirical case study, and the final section presents some conclusions.

sec.title: Research methodology
sec.p: In this section, some of the concepts and methods used in this paper are briefly introduced. These include triangular fuzzy numbers and algebraic operations, linguistic variables and ranking of fuzzy numbers respectively.

sec.title: Triangular fuzzy numbers and the algebraic operations
sec.p: In a universe of discourse X, a fuzzy subset A of X is defined by a membership function fA(x), which maps each element x in X to a real number in the interval [0,1]. The function value fA(x) represents the grade of membership of x in A.
A fuzzy number10A in the real line ℜ is a triangular fuzzy number if its membership function fA:ℜ→[0,1] is
with −∞<c≤a≤b<∞. The triangular fuzzy number can be denoted by (c,a,b).

The parameter a gives the maximum grade of fA(x), i.e. fA(a)=1; it is the most probable value of the evaluation data. In addition, c and b are the lower bound and upper bound respectively of the available area for the evaluation data. They are used to reflect the fuzziness of the evaluation data. The narrower the interval [c,b], the lower is the degree of fuzziness of the evaluation data.
Let A1=(c1,a1,b1) and A2=(c2,a2,b2) be fuzzy numbers. According to the extension principle,9 the algebraic operations of any two fuzzy numbers A1 and A2 can be expressed as follows:

list-item.p: fuzzy addition ⊕ given by
fuzzy multiplication ⊗ given by

sec.title: Linguistic variables
sec.p: In this paper, linguistic variables8 are represented by triangular fuzzy numbers, which are employed to express the fuzzy relationship degree between customer requirements and solutions of the service quality. According to the practical needs and in order to match the fuzzy QFD approach developed in this paper, the fuzzy relationship degree set is defined as S={High,Medium,Low,Non}. The linguistic values can be defined as High = (0.4, 0.8, 1), Medium = (0.3, 0.5, 0.7), Low = (0, 0.2, 0.6) and Non = (0, 0, 0) respectively.

sec.title: Ranking of fuzzy numbers
sec.p: In a fuzzy decision-making environment, ranking the alternatives under consideration is essential. To match the fuzzy QFD approach developed in this paper, and to solve the problem powerfully, the graded mean integration representation (GMIR) method, proposed by Chen and Hsieh11 in 2000, is employed to determine the priority order of execution to all technical solutions.
Let Ai=(ci,ai,bi),i=1,2,…,n, be n triangular fuzzy numbers. By the GMIR method, the GMIR value P(Ai) of Ai is
Suppose that P(Ai) and P(Aj) are the GMIR values of the triangular fuzzy numbers Ai and Aj respectively. We define

sec.title: Basic concept of the QFD model
sec.p: The QFD model12–15 can be used to translate customer requirements into product specifications. It is a tool to employ the voice of the customer (VOC) in a search for the best product development solutions. Cohen12 proposed a four-phase QFD model in a discussion of product development; these phases respectively consist of customer requirement planning (CRP), product characteristics deployment, process and quality control, and operative instruction. In this paper, we focused on the CRP phase, which is used to develop procedures for identifying customer requirements and solutions of the service quality. The CRP consists of the use of a matrix, known as the ‘house of quality (HOQ)’, which utilizes matrices to show multiple relationships between customer requirements (i.e. ‘what’ attributes of the service quality) and technical specifications (i.e. ‘how’ aspects (or solutions) of the service quality). In this paper, the matrices of the HOQ are used to organize the service quality of customer requirements and to establish the priorities of solutions in order to meet the requirements of the service quality.
A typical HOQ chart (American style) is shown in Figure 1 and is created in six basic steps.

list-item.p: Area A represents the customer needs, which is the VOC to be identified. In this paper, those needs are termed requirements, and they influence solutions of the service quality. The service qualities of customer requirements are determined via a questionnaire.
Area B represents the relative importance of the service qualities of customer requirements which are determined in this paper by means of the questionnaire.

Area C represents the design requirements or technical specifications, which are ‘how’ solutions of the service quality that are to be determined. In this paper, this ‘how’ question is the main issue and involves identification of solutions of the service quality.
Area D represents the relationship matrix, which is the core element of the HOQ. In this paper, the relationship strength is expressed by triangular fuzzy numbers.
Area E represents the correlation matrix, which expresses how the design requirements affect each other. Correlations are shown with symbols, a rating scheme of 1–3–9 or linguistic expressions.
Area F represents the design requirement target values. In this paper, the priorities of solutions of the service quality are calculated.

sec.p: The difference between the American-style HOQ chart and the Japanese-style HOQ chart is that the latter lacks area E in Figure 1. Since the Japanese-style HOQ is easy to use, however, it will be employed in this paper.

sec.title: The systematic steps of the fuzzy QFD approach
sec.p: The systematic steps of the fuzzy QFD approach4,6,7 are proposed as follows.

sec.title: Step 1: identify the service quality of customer requirements.
sec.p: Because the service quality of customer requirements is not easy to obtain, we combined determination of the service quality of customer requirements via the academic literature1,3,4,16–25 with consultation with managers and experts in Taiwan concerning the characteristics of the service quality of the PLSPs. As a result, six dimensions with 34 attributes of the service quality of customer requirements for an international PLC are evaluated, and their codes are shown in parentheses.

list-item.p: Distribution (F1). This dimension includes the nine attributes of ‘multi-modal transport services (C1)’, ‘provision of door-to-door delivery for international customers (C2)’, ‘provision of temperature-controlled transport service (C3)’, ‘provision of transport service for special cargoes (C4)’, ‘the speed of cargo distribution (C5)’, ‘effective cargo distribution (C6)’, ‘safe cargo distribution (C7)’, ‘triangular trade service (C8)’ and ‘special project service (C9)’ respectively.

Cost and efficiency (F2). This dimension contains the eight attributes of ‘warehousing cost (C10)’, ‘transport cost (C11)’, ‘logistics operation cost (C12)’, ‘convenience of geographic location (C13)’, ‘customs clearance convenience (C14)’, ‘port operation efficiency (C15)’, ‘logistics centre operation efficiency (C16)’ and ‘warehousing operation and management (C17)’ respectively.

Information services on cargoes (F3). This dimension has the five attributes of ‘verification of product codes (C18)’, ‘convenience of information transfer (C19)’, ‘accuracy of information transfer (C20)’, ‘electronization of operation procedures (C21)’ and ‘tracking of cargo information (C22)’ respectively.

Warehousing service (F4). This dimension includes the six attributes of ‘the security of the cargoes in the warehouse (C23)’, ‘provision of a temperature-controlled warehousing service (C24)’, ‘provision of a bonded warehouse (C25)’, ‘warehousing of special cargoes (C26)’, ‘loading and unloading management (C27)’ and ‘less than container load services (C28)’ respectively.

Supporting service (F5). This dimension contains the three attributes of ‘value-added services (e.g. sorting, processing, packaging and labelling) (C29)’, ‘business agency service (C30)’ and ‘customs declaration and clearance service (C31)’ respectively.

Customer service (F6). This dimension has the three attributes of ‘accident handling (C32)’, ‘attention paid to customer interest and equity (C33)’ and ‘response to customer complaints (C34)’ respectively.

sec.title: Step 2: Compare the importance and satisfaction levels of the attributes
sec.p: The attributes of the service quality of customer requirements can be measured using a Likert five-point scale4,7 to evaluate the discrepancies between the levels of perceived importance and satisfaction. If the latter are greater than the former, it implies that the service qualities of customer requirements in PLCs are acceptable. On the other hand, if the former are greater than the latter, it implies that some measures or solutions should be identified, and then proceed with Step 3. In this paper, we shall evaluate these discrepancies in the perceptions of the attributes of the service quality of customer requirements via questionnaires.

sec.title: Step 3: Identify technical solutions
sec.p: The direction of this ‘how’ issue is considered from the technical specifications involved in identifying solutions of the service quality, which are obtained from the academic literature1–4,18–21,24,26–30 and experts in PLCs. Three dimensions with 11 technical solutions of the service quality are suggested, and their codes are shown in parentheses. Descriptions of all technical solutions are shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Technical solutions of the service quality for the international PLC.

tr.td: Improvement in the service staff’s attitude can raise customer satisfaction with the service quality
Strengthening of the service staff’s professional ability can increase customer satisfaction with the service quality
Improvement in the service staff’s response ability can increase customer satisfaction with the service quality
With a round-the-clock enquiry system, customers can enquire about the conditions of their cargoes at any time
One-stop service allows customers to finish all required procedures for logistics service at the same counter
A simplified administrative procedure within a logistics centre can accelerate the operation process and shorten customers’ waiting time
Adequate warehousing space can satisfy customers’ demands for cargo storage

A logistics centre should ensure the security of cargoes stored in its warehouses. Hence, strengthening of the warehouse security management can reduce the risk of theft of, shortage of and damage to the cargo and can raise the centre’s service quality
A logistics centre should also ensure the integrity of cargoes in the process of transport
A logistics centre needs to monitor closely the condition of cargoes both in its warehouses and in the process of transport
For any damage to cargoes in the warehouse or during transport, a logistics centre should have a sound claim settlement system to follow for related compensations

sec.title: Step 4: Calculate the priorities of the service quality of customer requirements
sec.p: As mentioned in Step 2, the degrees of importance and satisfaction of each attribute of the service quality of customer requirements are compared to obtain the arithmetic means of all importance and satisfaction levels. The priorities of the service quality of customer requirements are calculated to evaluate the VOCs. Referring to area A in Figure 1, the identified VOCs include those in both the higher importance levels and the lower satisfaction levels, which implies that, the more the service quality of customer requirements is improved, the higher is the satisfaction.

Let Ii¯ and Si¯, i=1,2,…,n, be the arithmetic means of the importance levels and the satisfaction levels respectively for each attribute Ci (i=1,2,…,n) of the service quality of customer requirements. The priority of each requirement has a direct relationship with the importance level, whereas the priority has an inverse relationship with the satisfaction level.4,7 Thus, the original priority vi of Ci can be denoted by vi=Ii¯(6−Si¯). To facilitate comparison with the priority, these weights are normalized and denoted by wi=vi/∑i=1nvi. Finally, the priority of each service quality of customer requirements can be found via this approach.

sec.title: Step 5: Construct the fuzzy relationship matrix
sec.p: A fuzzy relationship matrix can be constructed to link the attributes Ci (i=1,2,…,n) of customer requirements and technical solutions Aj (j=1,2,…,m) of the service quality. Let xijh=(oijh,pijh,qijh), h=1,2,…,E, be the fuzzy relationship degree of the ith attribute of customer requirements corresponding to the jth technical solution evaluated by the hth expert. The linguistic relationship strength Rij in the position (i,j) of the matrix can be calculated from
where

For example, five experts evaluate High, High, Medium, Non and Low respectively for C1 corresponding to A1; then the fuzzy relationship strength can be evaluated from (0.22, 0.46, 0.66). Therefore, the fuzzy relationship matrix R can now be obtained and is R=[Rij]n×m.

sec.title: Step 6: Calculate the fuzzy weights of the technical solutions
sec.p: Let Rij=(oij,pij,qij), i=1,2,…,n;j=1,2,…,m, be the fuzzy relationship strength between the attributes Ci (i=1,2,…,n) of the service quality of customer requirements and the technical solutions Aj (j=1,2,…,m). The fuzzy weight FWj of technical solution Aj relative to all attributes of the service quality of customer requirements can be expressed as

sec.title: Step 7: Defuzzify the fuzzy relationship strength to rank the priority
sec.p: The GMIR method, which is discussed in the section on the ranking of fuzzy numbers, is used to defuzzify the fuzzy weight FWj of the technical solution Aj. The ranking value P(FWj) of FWj can be calculated from
Based on these ranking values and the ranking rules in the section on the ranking of fuzzy numbers, we can obtain technical solutions of the service quality.

sec.title: Case study
sec.p: In this section, a case study for an international PLC (hereafter called the PLC Z) in Taiwan is carried out to demonstrate the calculation procedures described above.

sec.title: Questionnaire and data collection
sec.p: In this paper, a first-stage questionnaire and a second-stage questionnaire were designed to evaluate the priorities of the service quality of customer requirements and the fuzzy relationship degrees between customer requirements and technical solutions. In the first-stage questionnaire, we used 34 attributes of the service quality of customer requirements to evaluate the degrees of importance and satisfaction. 100 members of staff in this field, including shipping carriers, shippers and ocean freight forwarders, were selected to answer the survey questionnaires. A total of 69 valid questionnaires were collected from 100 respondents, which represents 69% of the total. The surveys were completed through emails, phone calls and in-person interviews by the present authors.

The reliabilities (Cronbach α) of the degrees of importance and satisfaction are 0.962 and 0.975 respectively, which were obtained using the statistical software SAS. Also, the questionnaire conformed to content and construct validities. The content of the questionnaire was developed through an examination of the academic literature and investigated the characteristics of the service quality of customer requirements at the PLCs via the views of managers and experts. A pre-test was also conducted. As a result, the content validity of the questionnaire was very good.

Regarding the second-stage questionnaire, we combined the 34 attributes of the customer requirements and the 11 technical solutions of the service quality to construct a matrix table evaluating the fuzzy relationship degree. Robbins31 suggested five or seven decision makers are suitable for dealing with group decision-making problems. Because the fuzzy relationship degree is generated by a professional committee, seven experts consisting of senior managers, most of whom had been working in this field for over 25 years, were selected to complete this stage of the questionnaire for this survey.

sec.title: Empirical results
sec.p: We used the systematic steps of the fuzzy QFD approach proposed above to obtain the final results, which are shown in Table 2. The detailed construction of the HOQ in Table 2 is described as follows.

caption.p: The results of solutions of the service quality for the PLC Z

fn.label: a
fn.p: The full names of all attributes and solutions can be found in the section on the systematic steps of the fuzzy QFD approach.

sec.p: First, the last four columns of Table 2 show Ii¯, Si¯, vi and wi respectively. The Likert five-point scale was designed in the first-stage questionnaire to measure the degrees of importance and satisfaction, and the data from 69 valid respondents were collected to calculate the arithmetic means. The results showed that the arithmetic means of the degrees Ii¯ of importance are all larger than the degrees Si¯ of satisfaction for each attribute Ci in Table 2. The rankings of the important attributes of the service quality of customer requirements for the PLC Z are then evaluated. The top five key attributes of the service quality of customer requirements are ‘provision of door-to-door delivery for international customers (C2)’, ‘accident handling (C32)’, ‘logistics centre operation efficiency (C16)’, ‘port operation efficiency (C15)’ and ‘transport cost (C11)’ respectively.

Second, the central part of Table 2 shows the fuzzy relationship matrix. Four linguistic expressions were designed in the second-stage questionnaire to measure the fuzzy relationship degree of each attribute Ci corresponding to each solution Aj. A committee of seven experts of senior managers was selected to calculate the fuzzy relationship matrix [Rij]n×m (see Step 5 in the section on the systematic steps of the fuzzy QFD approach). After obtaining the fuzzy relationship matrix, we used Step 6 and Step 7 in the section on the systematic steps of the fuzzy QFD approach to calculate the fuzzy weights FWj, the GMIR values and the ranking values P(FWj) of all technical solutions. The technical solutions were ranked on the basis of the ranking rules in the section on the ranking of fuzzy numbers, and these results are shown in the last three rows of Table 2.

Finally, the empirical results showed that the top five best feasible solutions of the service quality of customer requirements for the PLC Z consist of ‘service personnel’s professionalism (A2)’, ‘a complete information system (A4)’, ‘the ability to track cargoes (A10)’, ‘service personnel’s response ability (A3)’ and ‘strengthening of warehousing security management (A8)’ respectively.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In summary, some discussion is given on the top five priorities for the quality technology deployment strategy only. Those solutions should be placed on the priority list for improvement in the service quality of international PLCs.

list-item.p: Service personnel’s professionalism. As service staff are the front-line personnel who have direct contact with the customers, they have a direct influence on the customers’ impression about a PLC. Also, because an international PLC can provide customers with professional logistics services, the service personnel’s professional ability is therefore extremely important. Accordingly, a PLC should provide their service staff with both pre-service and in-service training to strengthen their professional abilities.

A complete information system. Each batch of cargoes that customers entrust to a PLC should be handled very carefully as they are an important source of business. Also, customers might wish to know the condition of their cargoes at any time. Accordingly, a PLC needs to have a set of information systems in place for customers to enquire about their cargoes online so that they obtain an idea of whether their cargoes can be delivered on time or not.

The ability to track cargoes. The PLSPs should treat customers’ cargoes as their own, and therefore the PLSPs should have a better understanding about the condition of the cargoes than their customers do. In addition to the condition of the cargoes in the warehouse, the current handling process and estimated completion time, the PLSPs should also closely follow the entire transport process and the accurate geographical locations of cargoes, so that they may answer enquiries from customers correctly at any time. Apart from the above-mentioned information system, the PLSPs should also install positioning systems on their trucks to track the transport process. Moreover, education and training for truck drivers should also be intensified and regulation should be set to require truck drivers to report regularly the condition of cargoes in the transport process.

Service personnel’s response ability. Most customers still need to rely on service staff to understand the condition of their cargoes and to have their enquiries answered. Consequently, in addition to the supposed professional ability, service personnel should also have the ability to respond quickly. The PLSPs should provide pre-service training in which case-based teaching should be used to make service staff understand all possible situations that they might encounter in the future, and how to react properly to them once they happen. This can improve service personnel’s ability to respond in a swift and appropriate manner and to meet customers’ needs at the same time.

Strengthening of warehousing security management. The PLSPs should assume full responsibility for the cargoes that their customers have entrusted to them for the entire process from their receipt of the cargoes to the delivery of the cargoes to their consignees. In particular, they need to pay attention to the security management when the cargoes are stored in their warehouses. To prevent the theft of and damage to cargoes and to ensure the security of the cargoes in the warehouse, an international PLC needs to intensify its surveillance system in and around the warehouses, to dispatch more security guards to patrol and to tighten the control of personnel in and out of the warehouses.

sec.p: Although other solutions are not as urgent as the top five priorities, they are closely associated with improvement in the service quality and therefore cannot be ignored. To maintain the correctness and timeliness of work on improvement in the service quality, it is necessary to continue to collect customers’ opinions on their demands and satisfaction to serve as a basis for future periodic evaluation of the QFD.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The aim of this paper is to apply a fuzzy QFD approach in order to prioritize solutions of the service quality of customer requirements for international PLCs in Taiwan. First, the paper examines HOQ matrices to facilitate handling of the ‘what’ and ‘how’ aspects of the QFD problem. However, there are situations in which information is incomplete or imprecise or there are views that are subjective or endowed with linguistic characteristics, creating a ‘fuzzy’ decision-making environment. Hence, the fuzziness-based QFD approach is used to solve the relationship between customer requirements (i.e. the ‘what’ attributes of the service quality) and technical specifications (i.e. the ‘how’ aspects (or solutions) of the service quality). Finally, the systematic steps of the fuzzy QFD approach were proposed.

An empirical analysis was conducted, using the PLC Z as a case study, to demonstrate the systematic appraisal process for prioritizing solutions of the service quality. A first-stage questionnaire and a second-stage questionnaire were designed to help to illustrate the operational process of the proposed appraisal model. First, we used 34 attributes of the service quality to evaluate the discrepancies between the levels of perceived importance and satisfaction in the first-stage questionnaire. A total of 69 valid questionnaires were collected from 100 respondents. Second, we constructed a matrix table to evaluate the fuzzy relationship degree in the second-stage questionnaire. Then, a professional committee with seven experts of senior managers evaluated the fuzzy relationship matrix. Finally, the results of empirical study were as follows.

list-item.p: The top five key attributes of the service quality of customer requirements are ‘provision of door-to-door delivery for international customers’, ‘accident handling’, ‘logistics centre operation efficiency’, ‘port operation efficiency’ and ‘transport cost’ respectively.

The top five feasible solutions of the service quality of customer requirements for the PLC Z are ‘service personnel’s professionalism’, ‘a complete information system’, ‘the ability to track cargoes’, ‘service personnel’s response ability’ and ‘strengthening of warehousing security management’ respectively.

sec.p: Moreover, the empirical results show that PLSPs should listen attentively to the VOCs to focus on improvements in the service quality of customer requirements. It is suggested that more attention should be paid to fulfil these customer requirements effectively and then to develop the ‘how’ issues of technical solutions of the service quality. Furthermore, discussions on technical solutions of the service quality in the future for PLSPs should focus on implications and strategies such as customer satisfaction, efficiency, speed, flexibility, reliability and cost-effectiveness.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
